text: : Here is what came to mind. .  Part 1
label: neutral

text: : Where did we come from Where did we come from? First, letâ€™s admit that nobody knows
label: neutral

text: : How do we come to know anything? Oftentimes, itâ€™s by reasoning about observations
label: neutral

text: : So, letâ€™s start with one of the simplest observations
label: neutral

text: : It appears that there is something rather than nothing
label: neutral

text: : Planets, trees, paperclips, and we ourselves appear to be here
label: neutral

text: : Most of us agree with this observation, and if we didnâ€™t, thereâ€™d be nothing to explain, so for sake of conversation, letâ€™s assume for now that we do in fact exist Supposing stuff does exist, it seems reasonable to ask how it got here - where did it come from? The fact that we think an explanation is needed here implies that we all share a certain idea of what counts as a good explanation
label: neutral

text: : Oil and vinegar is a good explanation for salad dressing; eating soap is a good explanation for getting sick; and the idea that the world is round is a good explanation for how a traveler moving in any straight line will eventually arrive where she started But itâ€™s easy to imagine how things could have been different
label: neutral

text: Salad dressing could have been made from other ingredients; the kid who ate soap might have already been sick from a stomach flu; and the world could have been more ovular in shape
label: neutral

text: So the fact that we think explanations are needed implies that certain things do demand explanation
label: neutral

text: And the fact that some explanations are better than others implies that we all have certain standards for what counts as a good explanation Letâ€™s explore some possible explanations for all this stuff in our world
label: neutral

text: First, it could be that it all came from nothing
label: neutral

text: But this seems like a pretty unsatisfying explanation because it doesnâ€™t actually explain anything
label: neutral

text: Even on the quantum scale, where photons appear to come from nowhere, we have no current explanation for how this happens
label: neutral

text: But just because we donâ€™t know the explanation doesnâ€™t mean it canâ€™t be explained one day according to natural laws
label: neutral

text: There are innumerable examples in history of solving mysteries in this way If we were to conclude that something came from nothing, then our definition of nothing must be wrong because if something came from it, then it wasnâ€™t really nothing to begin with
label: neutral

text: Thatâ€™s just true by definition
label: neutral

text: Something can surely come from something else
label: neutral

text: Of course, this explanation might not be immediately satisfying because it implies an infinite regress of causes - a cosmic passing of the buck
label: neutral

text: We have an intuition that there must be a first cause - the original stuff
label: neutral

text: The problem is that if there is a first cause, weâ€™re right back at square one, looking for an explanation for that stuff Itâ€™s in situations like these that we should reflect on our assumptions and whether they could be wrong
label: neutral

text: Ok, but if we think this, weâ€™ve drastically lowered our bar for what counts as a good explanation
label: neutral

text: All along weâ€™ve been assuming that nothing means there is objectively nothing present, and infinity refers to something that is objectively endless
label: neutral

text: We think of them as polar opposites
label: neutral

text: So nothing and infinity have something interesting in common
label: neutral

text: When we try to describe them at the elemental level, we can describe them both as energetic states
label: neutral

text: Thereâ€™s an adage that fish will be the last to discover water
label: neutral

text: This is an apt analogy here because it shows how one and the same substance can be perceived as both vast and absent, depending on oneâ€™s point of view
label: neutral

text: Fish might not notice water because it uniformly permeates everything in their world, much like humans once believed that the air in our atmosphere is empty space; to a bird, of course, there is nothing empty about air In daily life, we think of nothing in an absolute sense because it appears to be empty, static, and uniform relative to our lived experience
label: neutral

text: But to mistake this state for truly nothing in an absolute sense just reveals our own bias - much like we conceive of the earth as being motionless
label: neutral

text: From a broader perspective, it can only be described as motionless relative to us This relational property of the universe means that nothing and infinity might not be polar opposites
label: neutral

text: Imagine a person who believes that the earth is flat and canâ€™t conceive of it being any other way
label: neutral

text: If this person were to travel in a perfectly straight line, say, Eastward, along the equator, eventually they would return to their origin point
label: neutral

text: The flat earther would be astonished
label: neutral

text: In their mind, East and West are polar opposites
label: neutral

text: So, they might think they had traveled through a wormhole hole
label: neutral

text: Of course, we know that East and West are not strict opposites, and the travelerâ€™s reappearing act can be easily explained by assuming the earth is spherical
label: neutral

text: But to achieve that understanding, we had to think in three dimensions instead of two
label: neutral

text: Likewise, the seemingly mysterious properties of nothingness and infinity could be an indication that they are not the polar opposites that they appear to be in our three-dimensional perspective, but are closely related properties of a higher-dimensional phenomenon The lesson here is that nothing and infinity could conceivably be, not absolute states, but relational states, two manifestations of a single fundamental entity
label: neutral

text: If emptiness and infinity are ultimately manifestations of the same thing, then itâ€™s meaningless to ask what caused stuff to come into being because, at the most fundamental level that we can comprehend, something has always been there
label: neutral

text: Itâ€™s the changes in that cosmic stuff, the temporary perturbations that, like waves on the oceanâ€™s surface, form the relational states that we know as life Itâ€™s a bewildering thought
label: neutral

text: And I'm the first to admit that I have no idea what lies beyond our three-dimensional existence
label: neutral

text: In the meantime, we have a choice: we can take that mystery on faith, or we can study it, measure it, test it, challenge and revise our own assumptions until we achieve, however slightly, a richer understanding of this amazing world we live in Part 2
label: neutral

text: How should we behave Holding aside questions about the nature of the universe, there remains a more practical question
label: neutral

text: But thereâ€™s reason to believe that itâ€™s not a lost cause
label: neutral

text: The challenge is this: to develop systems of cooperation that sustain themselves on the basis of rules that are likely to be honored by individuals with competing interests
label: neutral

text: But thatâ€™s a hard sell because sometimes it also feels good to be selfish, so this makes it hard to know when to follow which motivation
label: neutral

text: Another motivation could be that itâ€™s ultimately in our best interest to make sacrifices now for greater gains later
label: neutral

text: For example, forgoing a paycheck now to finish a high-school education could help a graduate cultivate the skills and resources they need to earn a larger paycheck later and serve both themselves and their community in a more effective way
label: neutral

text: Giving up drinking now could help someone be a better parent, which in turn will tend to help to raise a healthier, more virtuous child, and thus a healthier future relationship that benefits both parties much more than the instant gratification that alcohol could bring
label: neutral

text: But for such a motivation to be adopted, people really need to believe it, and to really believe it, it needs to usually prove itself true
label: neutral

text: They are systems of rules that purport that good things will come to those who follow their rules
label: neutral

text: But does the Golden Rule always deliver on its promises? Of course not
label: neutral

text: Itâ€™s just a rule of thumb
label: neutral

text: Many of these great efforts to get people to follow the rules have won the hearts of particular individuals
label: neutral

text: But none of them have won the hearts of all mankind
label: neutral

text: I think this is because, for some people to be adequately motivated, they require stronger evidence that the rules will tend to deliver on their promises
label: neutral

text: For many people, that means discovering a set of rules that generate payoffs in this lifetime So, how can we discover such a set of rules? The scientific method suggests that we should be able to discover such rules through the systematic observation of our own worldâ€”thatâ€™s the only place we can observe after all
label: neutral

text: One starting point might be to observe the people for whom the rules are clearly not working: the downtrodden, who have labored hard each day simply for a roof over their head and a meal in their belly, and still have nothing to show for it
label: neutral

text: The sinners, who abuse others for personal gratification
label: neutral

text: To do that, we need to study whatâ€™s failing them
label: neutral

text: Is it a systemic, economic problem, like the lack of mechanisms for upward mobility? Is it the lack of mental health resources necessary to persist in the face of these obstacles? A combination? There may be hundreds, or thousands, of barriers to thriving, and the prevalence of these societal problems is evidence that much more work is needed to be done to identify the changes to the rulebook that are needed to promote thriving
label: neutral

text: But a partial answer is that stealing is wrong to the extent that we can consistently demonstrate situations in which individuals who forgo stealing from one another both do better in the long run
label: neutral

text: We have vast libraries of scientific knowledge about how matter behaves and the rules of what can cause what
label: neutral

text: The cost of getting in a serious car accident while driving to the grocery store on a given day is certainly worse than the cost of not driving to the store that day
label: neutral

text: And if the odds of getting into an accident were 50/50, it would indeed be rational to stay home and order your groceries online, even if thatâ€™s more expensive in the short term
label: neutral

text: But the odds of getting into a car accident on a given day are not 50/50, and we know this from hard data
label: neutral

text: The risk is not zero, but itâ€™s small enough that we could justifiably conclude that driving to the grocery store is worth the risk
label: neutral

text: But as we have discussed, we have other good reasons for being good Most of us are seekers of truth, but we vary in our standards of proof for deciding whatâ€™s true
label: neutral

text: Those who adopt a scientific perspective are not ready to give up on natural explanations because, over the long term, their approach has an unsurpassed track record
label: neutral

text: This is because they commit themselves to an extremely high standard of proof
label: neutral

text: Today, I briefly return with some reflections on a few relatively recent theodicies, I've come across that I think are difficult to respond to

text: Be it the occurrence of evil and suffering generally, or more concrete horrific examples of evil or suffering such as a Fawn burning to death in a forest fire

text: There is taken to be two kinds of problem of evil
label: neutral

text: An evidentia , and a logica version
label: neutral

text: A logical problem of evil, argues that theism and the occurrence of evil are jointly inconsistent
label: neutral

text: There are many ways to formulate such an argument that atheist philosophers have come up with, there are inductive formulations, intuition-based formulations, Bayesian formulations etc
label: neutral

text: One would be a defense, another would be a theodicy
label: neutral

text: A defense is a response to a logical problem of evil, it is a story one can tell, which, when conjoined with theism, makes theism and the existence of evil compossible
label: neutral

text: The most famous example is Alvin Plantinga's free will defens
label: neutral

text: It's important to note that, a defense, does not need to be remotely likely, or plausible, it only needs to be true for all one knows and not entail a logical contradiction A theodicy, on the other hand, is a response to the evidential problem of evil
label: neutral

text: Unlike a defense, a theodicy must be a story which is plausibly actually true, not just true for all one knows
label: neutral

text: Before reading this section, I highly recommend watching Apologetic Squared's short 7 minute vide on this theodicy or reading the original pape on it
label: neutral

text: I will just give a brief sketch of it The basic idea is this; what makes me, me, and you, you, is our essential properties
label: neutral

text: And, the story goes, our essential properties include (and are possibly exhausted by) facts about our origins, indeed very specific facts about our origins, including the total causal history which has resulted in ones coming-to-be, our ancestral history, and evolutionary history
label: neutral

text: But this history includes a lot of suffering
label: neutral

text: This seems reasonably plausible on it's own
label: neutral

text: It seems like, at least partly, what would make me numerically distinct from an identical clone of myself would be my origins
label: neutral

text: Perhaps my clone was created in a test-tube using my DNA, whereas I was created through regular human reproduction etc
label: neutral

text: So my origins are an essential property of me, if those weren't my origins, I wouldn't be me
label: neutral

text: This strikes me as unintuitive in the extreme
label: neutral

text: While an object like you are me, could not have a entirely different origin, it seems like we could have a slightly different origin
label: neutral

text: That is, it seems like some degree of modal tolerance is permissable
label: neutral

text: Suppose I didn't believe my great grandfather fought in the first world war, but then my father tells me he did
label: neutral

text: It doesn't seem, in the slightest, that I'm learning about who I am, that is, learning about my essential characteristics
label: neutral

text: Or that, if it later turned out my grandfather did not fight in WW1, I would be finding out that I'm a different person than I previously thought I was, that seems utterly bizarre
label: neutral

text: On the other hand, if I found out that I am a brain in a vat, or a clone created in a test-tube, it seems like I would indeed be shocked to find out that I am not who I thought I was! But then, if not every fact about our origins is essential, what facts are and aren't? On reflection, one answer with some plausibility, is the essential part of my origin is the event of my father's sperm fertilizing my mother's egg, and the set of pre-natal embryonic states which followed etc
label: neutral

text: That is, what is relevent to an object or persons origins, is the causal history of the material out of which it was originally constituted
label: neutral

text: What makes the desk on which I am typing, *this* desk, is the history of the wood and nails which constitutes it
label: neutral

text: A view such as this is often used in tandum with Kripke's causal theory of reference
label: neutral

text: For a technical paper on this see her But suppose we even grant (as I would not) that every state of affairs which forms part of the causal chain ultimately leading to my birth, stretching back even to specific facts related to our evolutionary history, are an essential part of my origins as the argument needs

text: There is now a further question
label: neutral

text: So your origin and my origin is surely the same or same enough, our existence/essential properties would be preserved
label: neutral

text: Yet, the extremely undesirable experiences felt by persons and sentient non-persons leading up to us, would be greatly diminished
label: neutral

text: So, it would seem phenomenal content does not necessarily depend on certain physical states, you can have different phenomenal contents despite changes in physical states

text: I will address this in turn Scott characterizes the origin essentialism he accepts as follows Assembly Origin Essentialism: If the materials from which a creature originated were assembled by a process that was too different, then that creature would not have existed
label: neutral

text: At first blush, there doesn't seem to be an issue
label: neutral

text: But, it is left ambiguous what is precisely meant by too different

text: Scott and I, are going to disagree on the threshold

label: neutral

text: At most a proponent of Assembly Origin Essentialism should allow a few minor changes to the process by which the materials  from which I arose are assembled such as the one in Forbes' example
label: neutral

text: On the other hand,  the miracles required in Waiting and Painless Evolution require big changes to the process

text: So my origin is not preserved in such cases
label: neutral

text: This, however, is not a requirement

text: Afterall, it doesn't seem like a T-Rex mauling a Brochosaurus alive, or even my mother's pre-birth agony, is absolutely necessary for me, or Bob's, or anybody elses origins
label: neutral

text: The material out of which we originated could have an identical, or, intuitively, an identical enough history, such that I am still me and you are still you, sans such horrors
label: neutral

text: So there are further burden-shifting grounds to reject Scott's claim My second argument is that accepting such a strong variant of origin essentialism yields a gain in explanatory power. .
label: neutral

text: That is a significant gain in explanatory power for the theist
label: neutral

text: I just have a couple points here
label: neutral

text: There seems to be no principled way to say when an origin becomes so different that it fails to preserve the existence of an organism other than never or always
label: neutral

text: And if we are antecedently attracted to Assembly Origin Essentialism, it isnâ€™t plausible to hold that a change in origin never yields a different organism
label: neutral

text: So we should say that any change at all in the process by which the materials of my origin were assembled yields a different mere duplicate of me rather than me
label: neutral

text: This argument has more bite than the other two, but I think it is defeasible
label: neutral

text: I agree that if you hold that any change whatsoever in the causal history of ones origins is a change in the essential properties of some object or organism then that does indeed eliminate vagueness and arbitrariness, and, prima facie, this does seem to be a problem for views which are restrictive
label: neutral

text: But, so too would positing that having any strands of hair, constitutes non-baldness, or positing that any collection of 2 or more grains of sand constitutes a pile
label: neutral

text: We have an intuitive, conventional understanding of what a pile is, and what non-baldness is, and these views, while having the virtue of eliminating vagueness, simply do not track our concepts
label: neutral

text: This is analogous to radical origin essentialism, it simply doesn't track my, and I think our shared intuitive understanding of what makes us, us, and I take myself to have illustrated why this is so, above
label: neutral

text: If vagueness is a cost of maintaining such a view, then it's one I gladly pay, with the hopes that one day we do discover a restrictive criterion for essentiality of origins, which avoids issues of vague predicates Objection 2 Suppose we forgo the first objection, and agree that a very radical kind of origin essentialism is true

text: It rests on the intuition that the existence of you, and you in particular, your mother and father, your best friends and the love of your life, and those people in the actual world who satisfy those descriptions in particular are valuable in themselves, for their own sake

text: But suppose I asked you what makes them valuable, or at least, why you value them so dearly
label: neutral
